title: Action FPS/TPS Project

decks.name: Game Mechanics
decks.description: Defines the fundamental rules, core loops, and player progression. Use this deck for high-level design specs.

cards.content:
Aiming Down Sights (ADS)

Define how the aiming mechanic works when players want precision shots.

**Consider:**
- How much zoom when aiming?
- Does movement slow down? By how much?
- How tight should weapon accuracy become?
- Transition speed in and out of ADS

This mechanic affects weapon balance - tighter accuracy while aiming means weapons can be less accurate from the hip.

Core Movement

Define how the player moves through the game world.

**Consider:**
- Walking vs running speeds
- Sprint duration (stamina system?)
- Crouch speed and use cases
- Acceleration and deceleration feel
- Jump height and air control

Movement speed affects encounter design and map scale.

Player Health & Damage

Define player survivability and combat pacing.

**Consider:**
- Base health amount
- Health regeneration (passive, medkits, both?)
- Time-to-kill targets
- Shield/armor systems?

This determines if your game is fast-paced (low health) or tactical (high health).

Reloading System

Define how ammunition management works.

**Consider:**
- Magazine-based or pool-based ammo?
- Standard reload vs tactical reload differences
- Can reloads be interrupted?
- Animation timing per weapon type

Reload mechanics create vulnerable moments - balance risk vs reward.

decks.name: Weapons
decks.description: The live database for all weapons. Add a new weapon as a card, then start its journey to create all production tasks.

cards.content:
Crossbow

A basic projectile weapon to start players with.

**Consider:**
- Damage per bolt
- Draw/charge time
- Projectile speed and arc
- Ammo capacity

Projectile weapons require leading targets - good for teaching players aim prediction.

> **Sub-Cards:** These tasks were created by starting this weapon's journey. Each journey step becomes a production task automatically!

Rifle

A versatile all-purpose weapon for mid-range combat.

**Consider:**
- Fire mode (full-auto, burst, semi-auto?)
- Damage per shot
- Rate of fire
- Magazine size and reload time
- Recoil pattern
- Hitscan vs projectile

Rifles are workhorses - reliable in most situations but not specialized.

Shotgun

A close-quarters weapon with spread damage.

**Consider:**
- Pellet count and spread pattern
- Damage per pellet
- Effective range and damage falloff
- Fire rate (pump action vs semi-auto?)
- Reload method (shell by shell or magazine?)

Shotguns should dominate close range but be weak at distance.

decks.name: Enemies
decks.description: Enemy units that the player will encounter. Add an enemy card, then start its journey.

cards.content:
Patrol Drone

A surveillance enemy that alerts others to player presence.

**Consider:**
- Health amount
- Patrol pattern behavior
- Detection range and FOV cone
- Attack damage if any
- Alert radius when spotting player

Surveillance enemies create tension - avoid them or deal with reinforcements.

The Screamer

A support enemy that debuffs players and calls for help.

**Consider:**
- Health and movement behavior (flee vs attack)
- Scream effect (slow? stun? damage?)
- Scream range and duration
- Cooldown between screams
- What enemies does it attract?

Support enemies force players to prioritize targets strategically.

Auto Turret

A stationary defensive emplacement.

**Consider:**
- Health and whether it can be destroyed
- Field of view arc
- Fire rate and damage
- Projectile type
- Can it be hacked or disabled?

Fixed defenses control map areas - rewarding players who find flanking routes.

decks.name: Maps
decks.description: Repository for map concepts. Add a map card, then start its journey.

cards.content:
Training Ground

The tutorial map where players learn basic controls.

**Purpose:**
- Teach movement mechanics
- Introduce weapon types
- Safe environment for experimentation

**Consider:**
- Linear or open design?
- How to communicate objectives without text?
- Difficulty curve

Tutorials should teach without feeling like lessons.

Urban Combat Zone

A close-quarters map with buildings and tight corridors.

**Consider:**
- Verticality (multiple floors?)
- Sight lines and cover placement
- Flanking routes
- Spawn point balance
- Lighting and visibility

CQC maps favor shotguns and mobility over long-range weapons.

Industrial Complex

A mid-to-long range map with open areas and cover.

**Consider:**
- Balance between open and covered areas
- Sniper positions and counter-play
- Objective placement
- Environmental hazards?

Larger maps reward positioning and long-range weapons.

decks.name: Design Notes
decks.description: Design documentation, meeting notes, and playtesting findings. Use this deck to capture design decisions and their rationale.

cards.content:
Design Meeting: ADS Mechanics

**Date:** Week 2
**Attendees:** Lead Designer, Combat Designer

**Decisions:**
- ADS will reduce movement speed by 40%
- Zoom level: 1.5x for most weapons
- Transition time: 200ms in, 150ms out

**Rationale:** We want aiming to feel responsive but create a meaningful trade-off with mobility.

**Related:** This informs the ADS mechanic implementation.

Design Meeting: TTK (Time To Kill)

**Date:** Week 3
**Attendees:** Full design team

**Target TTK:**
- Close range: Define appropriate timing
- Mid range: Define appropriate timing
- Long range: Define appropriate timing

**Rationale:** Longer TTK encourages tactical play and teamwork over twitch reflexes.

Playtesting Notes: Map Flow

**Session:** Week 5 - Urban Combat Zone
**Issues Found:**
- Players getting lost in building interiors
- Too many camping spots
- Spawns too close to objectives

**Action Items:** Add more visual landmarks, reduce corner count, move spawns back.
